misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Array Indexing Starts at 1 (Off-by-One Notional Machine Model)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are 1-based (valid positions are 1..N), so the first element is at index 1 and the last element is at index N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indices are 0..N-1. Using 1..N causes attempts to access index N (out of bounds) and ignores index 0, breaking both input storage and the shift logic.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException during input and/or shifting/printing for any arraySizeInput > 0. No correct shifted output is produced except the trivial N=0 case (prints an empty list).

evidence.code_snippet:
// I think the last element is at position arraySizeInput
int lastElementTemporaryHolder = userInputArray[arraySizeInput];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are indexed starting from 1, not 0. They think the first element of an array is at position 1, the second at position 2, and so on. Therefore, for an array of size N, the last element should be at index N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use 0-based indexing. The first element is at index 0, the second at index 1, and for an array of size N, the last element is at index N-1. The student's mental model treats arrays as if they follow 1-based indexing (like some mathematical notations or other languages), which fundamentally misaligns with Java's actual behavior.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The code will crash with an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when attempting to read input, because when arrayIndexCounter reaches arraySizeInput and the code tries to access userInputArray[arraySizeInput], it attempts to access an index that doesn't exist (arrays of size N only have valid indices 0 to N-1). Even if this didn't crash, the shift logic and output logic would only process indices 1 through N-1, leaving index 0 untouched and skipping the actual last element at index N-1.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think arrays have elements from 1 to arraySizeInput, so I will start from 1
// I think the last element is at position arraySizeInput
// Place the original last element at the first position (which I think is index 1)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are indexed starting from 1 up to the length of the array (N), rather than from 0 to N-1.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use 0-based indexing. The first element is at index 0 and the last element is at index length - 1. Using index 'length' triggers an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are indexed from 1 to N, so the first element is at index 1 and the last element is at index N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indices are 0 through length-1. Using 1..N causes out-of-bounds access and also leaves index 0 unused/uninitialized relative to the intended input.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) for any arraySizeInput > 0, including the sample input.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think arrays have elements from 1 to arraySizeInput, so I will start from 1

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Confusing array length with last valid index
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if an array has size N, the last element is stored at index N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: For an array of length N, the last valid index is N-1. Accessing index N is always out of bounds and will crash the program.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when reading/storing the 'last element' and during the shift loop because it writes to index arraySizeInput.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are indexed starting from 1, similar to how we colloquially refer to positions (1st, 2nd, 3rd). They think that for an array of size N, valid indices go from 1 to N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are 0-indexed. For an array of size N, valid indices are 0 to N-1. The first element is at index 0, not index 1. Attempting to access index N (or any index >= N) results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime. When the user enters size 4, the code creates an array with indices 0-3, but immediately tries to access and assign to index 4 during input reading, causing a crash. The program never produces the correct output.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think arrays have elements from 1 to arraySizeInput, so I will start from 1
// I believe position 1 should be the first element

// I think the last element is at position arraySizeInput
int lastElementTemporaryHolder = userInputArray[arraySizeInput];

// I think I should go from the last element down to the first (1)
int shiftIndex = arraySizeInput;

// I think the elements go from 1 to arraySizeInput
int printIndexCounter = 1;

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays use a 1-based indexing system where the first element is located at index 1 and the last element is located at the index corresponding to the length of the array (N).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use zero-based indexing. The valid indices for an array of size N are 0 through N-1. The student's mental model treats the array as a 1-to-N structure, leading them to ignore index 0 for storage and attempt to access index N, which is out of bounds.
